verses.text: O Lord Almighty, God of Israel, the soul in anguish and the troubled spirit cries out to you.
verses.comment: The prayer begins with a heartfelt appeal to the Lord, reminiscent of the penitential psalms, showing a posture of humility before God.
verses.sectionHeader: A Prayer for Mercy and Confession of Sin

verses.text: Hear, O Lord, and have mercy, for we have sinned against you.
verses.comment: Reinforces the confession of sin, key to authentic repentance and restoration with God.

verses.text: For you are enthroned forever, and we are perishing forever.
verses.comment: This verse contrasts God's eternal reign with human frailty, expressing Israel’s lament during exile; it echoes Lamentations 5:19–20 and emphasizes the perpetual sovereignty of God against the transience of human suffering, inviting repentance and trust in divine mercy.

verses.text: O Lord Almighty, God of Israel, hear now the prayers of the people of Israel, the children of those who sinned before you and did not obey the voice of the Lord their God; so that calamities have clung to us.
verses.comment: The plea acknowledges inherited consequences of ancestral sin (Deuteronomy 5:9), highlighting corporate repentance and intergenerational responsibility while calling upon God's mercy for the present generation.

verses.text: Do not remember the transgressions of our ancestors, but remember at this time your power and your name.
verses.comment: The plea is for God’s mercy, not based on merit, but on His faithfulness and glory.

verses.text: For you are the Lord our God, and we, O Lord, will praise you.
verses.comment: Affirms the covenant relationship and worship due to God alone.

verses.text: For this reason, you have put the fear of you in our hearts, to call on your name. And we will praise you in our exile, for we have removed from our hearts all the injustice of our ancestors who sinned before you.
verses.comment: Describes the communal renewal and repentance, important for both restoration and spiritual transformation.

verses.text: See, today we are in exile, where you have scattered us. We are a curse and reproach, because of all the sins of our ancestors, who turned away from the Lord our God.
verses.comment: A direct acknowledgment of the consequences of sin, emphasizing divine justice and human responsibility.

verses.text: Hear, Israel, the commandments of life. Give ear to understand wisdom.
verses.comment: Wisdom and obedience are linked; life is found in heeding the Lord’s precepts.

verses.text: Why, Israel, why are you in the land of your enemies, growing old in a foreign country, defiled with the dead, counted among those in Hades?
verses.comment: Using ‘Hades’ signifies alienation from God; ritual purity and separation from pagan influence are highlighted.

verses.text: You have forsaken the fountain of wisdom.
verses.comment: God is depicted as the source of wisdom; neglecting Him brings spiritual death.

verses.text: If you had walked in the way of God, you would have lived in peace forever.
verses.comment: True peace is described as the fruit of obeying God's commands, both individually and communally.

verses.text: Learn where is wisdom, where is strength, where is understanding, so you may also know where is length of days and life, where is the light of the eyes and peace.
verses.comment: Echoes wisdom literature, identifying wisdom with life, light, and peace.

verses.text: Who has found her place? Who has entered her treasuries?
verses.comment: Wisdom’s hiddenness points to the mystery of God’s will, accessible only through revelation.

verses.text: Where are the rulers of the nations, those who lorded over the beasts of the earth?
verses.comment: Earthly power is shown to be transient compared to the enduring wisdom of God.
verses.sectionHeader: The Search for Wisdom Among the Nations

verses.text: Those who entertained the birds of the heavens and stored up silver and gold in which people trusted, whose possessions had no end.
verses.comment: Material wealth and worldly influence are contrasted with true wisdom.

verses.text: They fretted for silver and were anxious about their works. Their works are unknown.
verses.comment: Focuses on the futility of pursuing wealth over wisdom.

verses.text: They have perished and descended to Hades; others have arisen in their place.
verses.comment: Affirms the transience of earthly power and the enduring nature of wisdom.

verses.text: Later generations have seen the light and dwelt on the earth, but they have not known the way of knowledge.
verses.comment: The pursuit of wisdom is presented as a journey, not automatically inherited.

verses.text: Nor have their children accepted it; they were far from her way.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the generational need for renewal and seeking of wisdom.

verses.text: No one in Canaan heard of wisdom; no one in Teman sought her.
verses.comment: God’s wisdom is depicted as hidden from the proud and those outside of His covenant.

verses.text: The descendants of Hagar, who seek wisdom from the earth, the merchants of Merra and Teman, the storytellers and truth-seekers, have not learned the way of wisdom or remembered her paths.
verses.comment: Human efforts alone cannot attain divine wisdom.

verses.text: the descendants of Hagar, who seek for understanding on the earth, the merchants of Merran and Teman, the story-tellers and the seekers for understanding, have not learned the way to wisdom, or given thought to her paths.
verses.comment: This verse highlights groups renowned for their pursuit of wisdom and knowledge—descendants of Hagar (often associated with Arabian tribes), traders from Merran and Teman (regions in Arabia noted for their commerce and wisdom traditions), and skilled story-tellers and seekers of understanding—yet asserts that true divine wisdom remains hidden from them. The language emphasizes that neither relentless searching nor worldly status guarantees access to godly wisdom, setting up the later revelation of wisdom as a divine gift to Israel.

verses.text: O Israel, how great is the house of God, how vast the territory that he possesses!
verses.comment: This verse exclaims admiration for the magnificence and vastness of God's dwelling and domain, emphasizing divine greatness and sovereignty.

verses.text: It is great and has no bounds; it is high and immeasurable.
verses.comment: Describes the immense and limitless dwelling or territory associated with wisdom or with God, emphasizing its transcendence beyond human comprehension.

verses.text: The giants were born there, who were famous of old, great in stature, expert in war.
verses.comment: Recalls the legendary giants (Nephilim/Rephaim), noted for their prominence, physical greatness, and martial skill, highlighting the futility of human strength apart from divine wisdom.

verses.text: God did not choose them, or give them the way to knowledge;
verses.comment: Explains that despite their fame and power, the giants were not recipients of God's election or divine wisdom, illustrating the primacy of God's choice.

verses.text: so they perished because they had no wisdom, they perished through their folly.
verses.comment: Concludes that the lack of wisdom and folly led to the downfall of the mighty; human greatness without God’s wisdom results in destruction.

verses.text: Who has gone up into heaven, and taken her, and brought her down from the clouds? Who has gone over the sea, and found her, and will buy her for pure gold?
verses.comment: This verse uses rhetorical questions to stress the inaccessibility of wisdom to human effort and alludes to motifs found in Job, emphasizing wisdom’s heavenly origin and the impossibility of acquiring her by worldly means.
verses.sectionHeader: God, the Source and Giver of Wisdom

verses.text: Who has gone over the sea, and found her, and will buy her for pure gold?
verses.comment: Restored original meaning concerning the search for wisdom over the sea and its incomparable value; corrected to match the thematic sequence and removed lines appropriated from verse 33.

verses.text: No one knows the way to her, or is concerned about the path to her.
verses.comment: States the hiddenness of wisdom; no human fully knows or seeks the true path to wisdom unaided.

verses.text: But the one who knows all things knows her, he found her by his understanding. The one who prepared the earth for all time filled it with four-footed creatures;
verses.comment: God’s omniscience and creative wisdom are highlighted: only He knows and discovers wisdom, as demonstrated by His acts of creation, reinforcing the uniqueness of divine understanding.

verses.text: He sends forth the light, and it goes; he calls it, and it obeys him with trembling.
verses.comment: Using poetic imagery, the verse personifies light as an obedient servant, affirming God's absolute command over creation (cf. Job 38:19-20; Psalm 147:15), and highlighting the reverent response of nature to its Creator.

verses.text: The stars shone in their watches, and were glad; he called them, and they said, "Here we are!" They shone with gladness for him who made them.
verses.comment: Stars are depicted as joyful and responsive beings (cf. Isaiah 40:26; Job 38:7), illustrating the universe's glad submission to the Creator's will and reinforcing cosmic order rooted in God's word.

verses.text: This is our God; no other can be compared to him.
verses.comment: Stars’ joy is a poetic way to express the beauty and harmony of God’s creation.

verses.text: He found the whole way to knowledge, and gave her to his servant Jacob and to Israel, whom he loved.
verses.comment: Affirms that God graciously revealed true wisdom and knowledge to Israel, highlighting the special covenantal relationship with God's people.

verses.text: He found the entire way of knowledge and gave it to Jacob, His servant, and to Israel, whom He loved.
verses.comment: God’s wisdom is revealed to His elect people; this sets a foundation for the concept of an authoritative tradition and covenant identity.
